dt: {bc}capable of being {d_link|extended|extend} or shaped by beating with a hammer or by the pressure of rollers
{bc}capable of being altered or controlled by outside forces or influences

pt: {sc}plastic{/sc} {sc}pliable{/sc} {sc}pliant{/sc} {sc}ductile{/sc} {sc}malleable{/sc} {sc}adaptable{/sc} mean susceptible of being modified in form or nature. {sc}plastic{/sc} applies to substances soft enough to be molded yet capable of hardening into the desired fixed form.

pt.t: {it}plastic{/it} materials allow the sculptor greater freedom

pt: {sc}pliable{/sc} suggests something easily bent, folded, twisted, or manipulated.
{sc}pliant{/sc} may stress flexibility and sometimes connote springiness.

pt.t: an athletic shoe with a {it}pliant{/it} sole

pt: {sc}ductile{/sc} applies to what can be drawn out or extended with ease.
{sc}malleable{/sc} applies to what may be pressed or beaten into shape.
{sc}adaptable{/sc} implies the capability of being easily modified to suit other conditions, needs, or uses.

quotes.t: The brothers Warner presented a flexible, {qword}malleable{/qword} world that defied Newton, a world of such plasticity that anything imaginable was possible.

The boy seemed to me possessed by a blind, invalid arrogance, and every human being, as his eye flicked over or flinched against them, became, immediately, as {qword}malleable{/qword} as his mother and his father.
At each landing the villagers had carved the wonderfully {qword}malleable{/qword} silt into staircases, terraces, crenellations, and ziggurats.

et: Middle English {it}malliable{/it}, from Medieval Latin {it}malleabilis{/it}, from {it}malleare{/it} to hammer, from Latin {it}malleus{/it} hammer {ma}{mat|maul|}{/ma}
